EXCHANGE --- Who Pays for Climate Change? --- An ex-central banker is leaning on big banks to commit to the U.N.'s green protocols. It can be a tough sell.

Author: McNish, Jacquie; Hoffman, Liz

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/exchange-who-pays-climate-change-ex-central/docview/2588205477/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=EXCHANGE+---+Who+Pays+for+Climate+Change%3F+---+An+ex-central+banker+is+leaning+on+big+banks+to+commit+to+the+U.N.%27s+green+protocols.+It+can+be+a+tough+sell.&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-30&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;au=McNish%2C+Jacquie%3BHoffman%2C+Liz&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=EXCHANGE+---+Who+Pays+for+Climate+Change%3F+---+An+ex-central+banker+is+leaning+on+big+banks+to+commit+to+the+U.N.%27s+green+protocols.+It+can+be+a+tough+sell.&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-30&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=B.1&amp;au=McNish%2C+Jacquie%3BHoffman%2C+Liz&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Diplomats heading to the United Nations climate conference in Glasgow next week know their governments can raise only a fraction of the trillions needed to cut carbon emissions and transition the energy market to renewables. They asked Mark Carney to come up with the rest.
Mr. Carney, the former head of central banks in Canada and the U.K., beseeched, cajoled and browbeat the world's top financiers to pay the bill. When that failed, powerful allies flexed their muscles.
"The world is watching," he said in an interview. "I am going to be judged. Everyone is going to be judged."
Can he pull it off? The answer will help determine one of the biggest open questions of the coming decades: Who pays for climate change? There is a general agreement among businesses, investors and the U.S. government that the country should become carbon neutral in the coming 30 years while limiting the climate costs already incurred. The challenge, however, is figuring out how to split the price of making that happen.
Mr. Carney's appeal to the global finance community is a crucial piece of the puzzle. Analysts say as much as $150 trillion is likely needed over the next three decades to fund renewable energy projects, upgrade electric grids, mothball fossil-fuel plants, seed new agricultural technologies, and pay for damages tied to climate change.
The Glasgow summit, the successor to the Paris conference that produced the 2015 climate accords, offers another forum to wrestle with these issues. This time, nations are under pressure to lay out clear plans to cut carbon emissions this decade and become carbon neutral by 2050. The aim is to limit global temperature increases to no more than 2 degrees Celsius from preindustrial levels, and preferably 1.5 degrees, thresholds above which many climate scientists warn of catastrophic and irreversible harm.
As the U.N.'s point man on climate-change finance, Mr. Carney had some early successes. He got commitments last spring from Citigroup Inc., Morgan Stanley and Bank of America Corp. to shift their money to businesses that reduce global carbon emissions. Big insurers and asset managers, too, signed on in large numbers.
The rest of Wall Street was a tougher sell. He encountered resistance at JPMorgan Chase & Co., Wells Fargo & Co. and Goldman Sachs Group Inc., where Mr. Carney spent 13 years. The major Canadian banks dragged their feet, too, another awkward setback for Mr. Carney, a native son who harbors political ambitions in the country. Most big banks from China, India, Japan and Australia haven't joined.
What he wanted the banks to do specifically was agree to steps outlined in a 14-page protocol written by the environmental arm of the United Nations. That would mean setting targets for less lending and investment in enterprises that produce carbon emissions; devoting more support to new, environmentally sustainable technologies; and publishing their progress on these targets each year. Banks would be under pressure to either push clients away from carbon emissions or drop those that don't comply.
Some of the biggest concerns from the banks were potential legal risks, the feasibility of measuring their total exposure to carbon emissions and how annual progress reports could be received by shareholders. Banks were particularly worried about getting lending and investment portfolios to net-zero emissions by 2050 or earlier. If a bank failed to reach net zero, would shareholders sue? Bank chief executives also fretted that climate promises might harm their successors if targets weren't met.
Supporters of Mr. Carney, such as the White House and U.K. Prime Minister Boris Johnson, put the screws to fellow financiers in ways that some found irritating. Large shareholders that belonged to his alliance prodded holdout banks. During the U.N. General Assembly meeting in late September, Mr. Carney walked through gridlocked traffic to lobby Goldman's CEO, David Solomon -- a stark reversal of roles from the days when Mr. Carney, the central banker, set the rules and Wall Street obeyed.
He appealed to their vanity. Banks that didn't commit by Oct. 15 wouldn't have their logos on Glasgow press materials. Their executives would miss out on prime speaking slots at the conference, Mr. Carney's staff warned.
One of Mr. Carney's biggest challenges would be convincing JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon, boss of the largest bank in the U.S. by assets. Mr. Dimon privately criticized Mr. Carney's effort as overly vague, people familiar with the matter said. He also worried that it would conflict with potential new regulations from the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, these people said.
Mr. Carney, 56, is the product of a remote town in Canada's Northwest Territories called Fort Smith, where the average January high is 0 degrees Fahrenheit and the motto inscribed on the town flag is "perseverance." His parents -- who moved to Edmonton, Alberta, while he was still young -- were teachers and volunteers in local community, church and school programs. He said they encouraged him to "give and serve."
Mr. Carney did well enough in school to attend Harvard University, where he studied economics and economic history and paid for schooling with a grant and student loans. He later got a master's degree and Ph.D. from the University of Oxford, in economics.
He joined Goldman because, he said, his brother had worked there and "I had an enormous sum of money in student loans" that needed to be paid off. It also allowed him to see the world; he helped countries such as South Africa, Japan and Russia dig their way out of economic crises in the 1990s. The work helped him understand, he said, the impact one could have in government and influenced his decision to leave so he could help set monetary policy and regulate banks. He was governor of the Bank of Canada from 2008 to 2013 and then governor of the Bank of England for seven years.
During his stay at the Bank of England he usually ran twice a week to his office -- roughly 9 kilometers from his West Hampstead home -- and did so without any security or bodyguards. "It was the best way to be on the streets and not get recognized," he said. "Surprisingly therapeutic."
He said he still jogs twice a week along the Ottawa River with friends who have been running with him for about 20 years. Except for winter months, his run ends with a plunge in a pond near his home in Rockcliffe Park, an affluent Ottawa neighborhood with heritage homes, foreign embassies and private schools. He said he also goes to Catholic church at least once a week, meditates and is a fan of Benedictine monk Laurence Freeman, the director of the World Community of Christian Meditation. His taste in music ranges from Nick Cave to Taylor Swift, whom he saw in concert while in the U.K.
Mr. Carney became increasingly critical of the financial industry in recent years. This spring he published a book titled "Value(s): Building a Better World for All" that he wrote during the pandemic. In it Mr. Carney, who experienced the aftershocks of the 2008-09 financial crisis in Canada and England, said he "worked to heal the malignant culture at the heart of financial capitalism."
His climate work began with what he assumed would be a short assignment. After leaving the Bank of England in 2020, he took on what he thought was a six-month job as U.N. special envoy on climate action and finance, a way to burnish his credentials with a private sector he hoped to re-enter. That six-month gig is now going on two years.
He launched the Glasgow Financial Alliance for Net Zero this spring. That set him off on a global recruiting effort to get financial companies to agree to set meaningful targets for reducing loans and investments to businesses that, directly or indirectly, are big emitters of greenhouse gases.
The campaign offered a new set of challenges for banks. Many had already backed away from the dirtiest investments, such as directly financing coal-fired power plants or new mines in ecologically sensitive spots. But the guidelines set by the U.N.'s environment arm would require that financial institutions first set public targets for shifting clients away from carbon emissions and then calculate the emissions produced by any investment long after the check was written -- a task made more complicated by the range of industries banks typically support.
A bond of bundled car loans, for example, would have to measure the gas burned by those vehicles. A letter of credit guaranteeing safe passage of an oil tanker would have to account for the carbon released when that crude is refined. It is not yet known how this tracking will work exactly and whether it might raise costs for banks or borrowers.
After an initial wave of bank sign-ups in the spring, Mr. Carney's recruiting campaign stalled. By early September, 28 of the world's largest 50 banks by assets had not joined, leaving just a month to deliver on his mandate before diplomats descended on Glasgow.
He tried to act like the regulator he once was, scolding banks in an August tweet: "If you're not part of the solution, you are the problem." He appealed to their greed, calling the fight against climate change "the biggest commercial opportunity in the world."
Neither strategy worked. His campaign struck many executives at holdout firms as both arrogant and toothless, likely to mire their firms in paperwork for decades and expose them to potential lawsuits from shareholders claiming they weren't doing enough. Similar blowback surfaced recently after banks signed a pledge not to fund oil drilling in the Arctic. Some investors and environmentalists say that pledge contains loopholes, and money has continued to flow from big banks to companies active in areas of Norway, Russia, Canada and Alaska rich in oil and gas.
Maggie Peloso, a climate lawyer advising several banks belonging to the alliance, said banks had legitimate reasons to be wary of agreeing to Mr. Carney's global agenda because local regulations are simultaneously shifting in countries where these institutions operate. "It's like trying to build the plane while you are flying it," she said.
Some resented being chided by one of their own. Evan Siddall, a former colleague at Goldman Sachs and the Bank of Canada, said Mr. Carney can get testy when people don't live up to his expectations. "He has a hubris and impatience that limits his ability to manage people," said Mr. Siddall, now the CEO of Alberta Investment Management Corp., a pension and government fund manager.
Mr. Carney said that while he is "not perfect" as a manager, he holds people to high standards in public service or in a crisis such as climate change because "there is very little margin for error."
Another move that attracted scrutiny was a more lucrative job Mr. Carney started last year. In August 2020, he became a vice chairman at Toronto-based Brookfield Asset Management Inc., which specializes in real-estate, infrastructure and renewable power investments. He now oversees investments designed to help with the transition to clean energy and runs a $7 billion fund chasing "positive social and environmental outcomes."
His dual role, as both green investor and an architect of a new global climate finance regime, has opened him up to questions about potential conflict of interest. In his U.N. role, he is pushing banks and investors to stop funding fossil-fuel producers and the like. At Brookfield, he's investing in companies that will benefit from a decline in those industries. Mr. Carney said the criticism of his job at Brookfield "doesn't make sense" because the company is a founding member of his alliance and has made the same commitment to reducing investments linked to carbon emissions.
He's also been criticized by some environmental groups for making it too easy for financial firms to appear eco-friendly while doing little of substance. "If there's one advantage of being a central-bank governor for 14 years," Mr. Carney said, "it's that you get used to being criticized on both sides."
As the Glasgow conference got closer, Mr. Carney increased pressure on the recalcitrant banks.
He and his political and industry allies pushed their big shareholders, who are under pressure from their own clients to use their financial firepower to combat climate change. Some major investors -- including Fidelity Investments and Canada's two largest pension funds -- have in recent weeks pressed some holdouts to the U.N. effort about either joining Mr. Carney's alliance or doing more to fight carbon emissions, people familiar with the matter said.
He turned to government officials to twist arms. U.S. banks that hadn't signed on to the U.N. alliance weren't invited to President Biden's climate summit this spring, people familiar with the matter said.
Mr. Carney's pressure started to pay off. In September, the U.K. prime minister came to New York and pressed Wall Street executives to do more on climate change. Mr. Carney also has a role as the prime minister's finance adviser for the climate conference. Mr. Johnson, as the host of the Glasgow conference, has tried to become the most environmentally conscious leader of a major economy.
A turning point came at a breakfast hosted by Mr. Johnson at a British diplomat's luxury Manhattan condo. As the event broke up, Daniel Pinto, a top executive at JPMorgan, pulled Mr. Carney aside. The bank -- named the world's largest lender to fossil-fuel companies in a report this year from several environmental advocacy groups -- was a high-profile holdout to the U.N. alliance even though it had already announced a pledge to align with the Paris climate agreement and work toward global net-zero emissions by 2050.
The bank's position was becoming harder to defend in the face of growing pressure from shareholders and governments. Investors had waged a vote-out campaign in 2020 against a longtime JPMorgan board member, former Exxon Mobil Corp. chief Lee Raymond, who stepped down at the end of that year. And months of internal work had convinced JPMorgan executives that Mr. Carney's goals were both achievable and profitable. The bank was in, Mr. Pinto told Mr. Carney.
A JPMorgan spokesman said Mr. Dimon supports Mr. Carney's alliance "and what it is aiming to achieve."
The five big Canadian banks -- major sources of fossil-fuel financing, given that country's rich energy reserves and expertise in drilling -- signed up next, along with Wells Fargo. Goldman Sachs was last in among the big U.S. banks. As of Friday, 34 of the world's biggest 50 banks had joined Mr. Carney's alliance.
Giant banks from China and India, two of the world's biggest carbon emitters, haven't signed up, and neither have most big banks from Japan and Australia. The Glasgow conference starts Monday and Mr. Carney said he is campaigning to the end.
"We have this massive problem, we have left it very late," Mr. Carney said.

Coal Use Stirs Clash At Climate Summit

Author: Sha Hua; Colchester, Max

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/coal-use-stirs-clash-at-climate-summit/docview/2588203879/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Coal+Use+Stirs+Clash+At+Climate+Summit&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-30&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Sha+Hua%3BColchester%2C+Max&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Coal+Use+Stirs+Clash+At+Climate+Summit&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-30&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Sha+Hua%3BColchester%2C+Max&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: ROME -- Leaders from the Group of 20 major economies are split over phasing out coal and limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, officials said, throwing into doubt whether ambitious climate-change targets can be hit.
The gathering of world leaders in Rome this weekend is expected to set the tone for talks at the nearly two-week United Nations climate summit in Glasgow, slated to follow immediately afterward.
G-20 nations, including the U.S., China, Russia, India and Saudi Arabia, will attempt to forge a common position on how best to adhere to the 2015 Paris climate agreement, which asks countries to start reducing their emissions as soon as possible and achieve a climate-neutral world by midcentury.
Officials said forging consensus on policies to achieve this remains difficult given the G-20's competing interests and that few concrete proposals are likely to come out of the summit.
Recent energy crises have also spurred leaders to rethink their stance on fossil fuels. In China, a coal supply shortage has led to major revisions of the country's carbon road map, elevating the importance of energy security and creating wiggle room for adding more coal plants, a person familiar with the discussions said.
Without a positive signal from G-20 leaders, agreement at COP26 -- as the Glasgow climate summit is known -- will be even harder to achieve, climate activists fear.
The G-20 and COP26 could be "mutually reinforcing or mutually weakening," said one senior official involved in the talks.
Italian Prime Minister Mario Draghi told Italy's Parliament this month that his country, which holds the G-20 presidency this year, hoped to achieve consensus among the group's leaders before the Glasgow conference.
"The climate crisis can only be managed if all major global players decide to act in an incisive, coordinated and simultaneous manner." Mr. Draghi said, noting that G-20 members account for about three-quarters of the world's carbon emissions.
The issue of coal will be a litmus test of G-20 leaders' political resolve. The group includes several heavy users and producers of the fossil fuel, including China, the U.S. and Australia. In July, G-20 environment ministers meeting in Naples couldn't agree to set dates for phasing out the use of coal and ending the building of new coal-fired power stations.
Coal-rich countries such as China, India and Australia emerged as vocal opponents of such targets, said people familiar with the talks, adding that Turkey, Russia and Saudi Arabia were also part of the camp.
Some countries fear that an agreement to phase out coal would quickly lead to pressure to wind down the use of other fossil fuels such as gas or oil, said Chris Littlecott, an associate director at climate consulting firm E3G.
A surge in fossil-fuel prices as economies reopened after lockdowns has led several countries, including China and the U.K., to lean on coal to power their industries and electricity supply.
Chinese President Xi Jinping said in April that China would begin "phasing down" its coal consumption in 2026. But neither China nor India, the second-most populous country in the world, is willing to commit to an end date or use the phrase "phase out" in relation to coal.
The action plan on how China plans to reach its carbon-dioxide peak before 2030, which was released by the State Council on Tuesday, said new constructions of coal plants needed to adhere to international energy efficiency standards. An earlier version of the plan made no mention of new coal-fired power plants, said the person familiar with the discussions, adding that a few renewable-energy targets had also been dropped from the final version, while a greater emphasis was placed on energy security.
Coal powers around 56% of China's industry-heavy economy and is regarded as vital for the country's energy security. It is unlikely China will even start considering this politically sensitive question until after the twice-a-decade Communist Party Congress in fall 2022, the person said.
China released its updated climate targets on Thursday, reiterating numbers said last year by Mr. Xi. China stuck to a pledge to start reducing its carbon emissions "before 2030," despite international pressure to begin earlier, and said it would achieve carbon neutrality before 2060.
China has signaled it is potentially more open to committing to ending overseas financing for coal use. "If they were to move on one issue, that would be the most likely," said Mr. Littlecott.
Mr. Xi said China would stop building overseas coal projects at the U.N. General Assembly in September. China had been the main holdout during the G-20 talks on the issue this summer, people said.
Developing countries such as China and India have said that it is more important to focus on implementing existing pledges first and providing financial support for poorer countries in their fight against climate change.
The G-20 summit will be the first in-person gathering of the leaders of the world's richest nations since the Covid-19 pandemic started, including President Biden and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi. At least four G-20 leaders aren't expected to travel to Rome, including Mr. Xi and President Vladimir Putin of Russia. Mr. Xi is expected to participate via a video link.
Credit: By Sha Hua and Max Colchester

Oil Giants Strike Gusher Of Cash as Demand Rises

Author: Matthews, Christopher M

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/oil-giants-strike-gusher-cash-as-demand-rises/docview/2588203870/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Oil+Giants+Strike+Gusher+Of+Cash+as+Demand+Rises&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-30&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Matthews%2C+Christopher+M&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Oil+Giants+Strike+Gusher+Of+Cash+as+Demand+Rises&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-30&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Matthews%2C+Christopher+M&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Big oil companies are generating their strongest cash flows in years and heeding investor calls to return it to shareholders instead of using it to drill.
The two largest U.S. oil companies, Exxon Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp., reported on Friday their most profitable quarterly earnings since before the onset of the global pandemic.
Exxon reported earnings of $6.8 billion, its best quarterly performance since 2017, and said it would launch a $10 billion share buyback program starting next year. Chevron reported $6 billion in net income, its best quarter since 2013, and said it generated $6.7 billion in free cash flow, its most ever.
The industry is reaping the rewards of resurgent commodity prices -- U.S. crude has topped $80 a barrel this month for the first time since 2014 -- as the economy emerges from the stagnation brought on by Covid-19 and the shutdowns used to fight it. Global energy demand is rebounding faster than anticipated, and world-wide oil production, while still rising, is struggling to catch up with the surge in consumption.
Investors and analysts are watching closely to see if the oil industry will succumb to the temptation of plowing more money into growing production amid higher oil prices and increased demand, shrugging off austerity measures implemented during the pandemic.
After years of dismal returns, investors have sought pledges from producers that they will moderate growth and focus on shareholder payouts.
Some investors want companies to diversify and pivot to renewable energy as many countries transition to cleaner power sources because of concerns about climate change.
So far, most companies are sticking to smaller budgets and pledging to return more cash to shareholders.
Exxon raised its quarterly dividend on Wednesday by 1 cent, its first such increase since 2019, and said Friday it generated $12 billion in cash from operations.
Chevron said Friday that its year-to-date capital spending is down 22% and it paid dividends of $2.6 billion, reduced debt by $5.6 billion, and repurchased $625 million of shares during the quarter.
"Free cash flow more than covered the dividend and $4 billion of additional debt reduction," said Exxon Chief Executive Officer Darren Woods. "With the progress made in restoring the strength of our balance sheet, this week we announced a dividend increase maintaining 39 consecutive years of annual dividend growth."
Shares of Chevron rose 1.2% Friday, while Exxon shares were nearly flat at Friday's market close.
European energy companies are also raking in cash but say they will continue to use more of it to fund renewable-energy projects and investor payouts than growing oil and gas production.
TotalEnergies SE reported $4.6 billion in profit Thursday and said that strong cash generation from fossil fuels is enabling it to invest in growing its renewable-energy and electricity businesses. Royal Dutch Shell PLC, which is facing calls by activist investor Third Point LLC to split into two companies, reported a loss of $447 million Thursday, after writing off $5.2 billion linked to commodity derivatives. But the Anglo-Dutch giant said it produced $16 billion in free cash flow, its most ever, and would distribute $7 billion to shareholders from the $9.5 billion sale of its shale assets in the Permian Basin to ConocoPhillips in September. BP PLC reports earnings next week.
Though oil prices are up around 60% on the year, 50 of the largest oil companies have increased their annual budgets by only 1%, according to Raymond James. The companies initially budgeted $271 billion and that has only ticked up to $275 billion, the financial firm said in a note to investors.
Mark Stoeckle, chief executive of Adams Funds, said that in past oil-price surges Western oil companies have ramped up drilling, outspending their cash flows in pursuit of higher valuations to the detriment of returns. But even before the pandemic, investors began fleeing the sector and conveying to oil executives and boards that the only way to entice them back was to moderate growth and offer fat payouts, according to Mr. Stoeckle. The current price cycle is the first test of that capital discipline.
While most producers appear to be abiding by investors' wishes for now, questions linger for some about how they will spend their money beyond that. Unlike their European peers, U.S. oil companies are largely not diversifying into renewable energy.
Chevron CEO Mike Wirth has repeatedly said that Chevron won't invest in wind or solar power generation because he doesn't think it can make a larger return in those businesses. Instead, Chevron will return cash to investors and "let them plant trees" if they choose to, he said in a television interview in September.
Both Chevron and Exxon created low-carbon business units this year that will primarily focus onbiofuels, hydrogen production, carbon capture and other technologies. Chevron tripled its planned investment in its unit in September, saying it would spend $10 billion through 2028. Exxon increased its low-carbon spending Friday, saying it would invest $15 billion on such projects from 2022 through 2027.
But the increased green investment still represents a fraction of what the companies are spending on oil and gas projects, and it is unclear how profitable the units will be for the foreseeable future. Many of the technologies they are investing in will need further government subsidies to be economically viable.
Not everyone thinks tighter budgets are a good thing. During a contentious congressional hearing Thursday, some Republican lawmakers urged Messrs. Wirth and Woods and executives from Shell and BP to increase their oil production to alleviate high prices. Democrats on the House Committee on Oversight and Reform convened the hearing after accusing the oil industry of waging a campaign to spread disinformation about fossil fuels' role in causing global warming.
Exxon has said it would keep production roughly flat. On Friday, it said quarterly production increased 4% from the same period last year.
Chevron is increasing production, modestly. Pierre Breber, its chief financial officer, said in an interview that the company's production was up 7% in the quarter compared with the same period last year and will increase 3% annually through 2025. But he said Chevron is unlikely to commission any mega-oil projects that take years to come online and years more to pay out. Instead it is planning to drill more shale wells in the U.S., which produce quickly but decline rapidly.
"This is a sector that is working hard to attract investors," Mr. Breber said. "We really believe the winning combination for investors is the traditional business that's high return, low growth, low carbon combined with faster growing new energy businesses."
Credit: By Christopher M. Matthews

U.S. News: Oil Executives Face Adversarial House Panel

Author: Katy Stech Ferek; Matthews, Christopher M

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/u-s-news-oil-executives-face-adversarial-house/docview/2587564891/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Oil+Executives+Face+Adversarial+House+Panel&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Katy+Stech+Ferek%3BMatthews%2C+Christopher+M&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Oil+Executives+Face+Adversarial+House+Panel&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.4&amp;au=Katy+Stech+Ferek%3BMatthews%2C+Christopher+M&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: WASHINGTON -- Democratic lawmakers went on the offensive against the oil industry Thursday, challenging top executives from Exxon Mobil Corp., Chevron Corp., BP PLC and Royal Dutch Shell PLC on whether they genuinely supported efforts to address climate change.
Democrats on the House Committee on Oversight and Reform accused the oil industry of waging a yearslong campaign to spread disinformation about the role of fossil fuels in causing global warming and lobbying against policies central to President Biden's $1.85 trillion social-policy and climate framework.
All four companies said that they have long acknowledged the threat of climate change and are cutting their carbon emissions to minimize their contributions to it.
"At Chevron, we have been very clear where we stand," Chevron Chief Executive Mike Wirth said. "We accept the scientific consensus: Climate change is real, and the use of fossil fuels contributes to it."
Democrats on the House committee said the companies publicly support climate-friendly policies and investments but privately work to derail regulations that would cut greenhouse gas emissions.
Rep. Ro Khanna (D., Calif.), chairman of the Subcommittee on the Environment, said that the American Petroleum Institute -- the industry's main lobbying group, which is funded by the companies -- is currently lobbying against Democrat-supported policies that he said would reduce emissions, including subsidies for electric vehicles and a methane tax.
"You're funding these groups, and they're really having an impact," Mr. Khanna told the executives. "Could you tell them to knock it off for the sake of the planet?"
API president Mike Sommers responded to allegations the group was lobbying against Democrat-backed climate change policies by saying the group supports market adoption of electric vehicles and renewable energy, but not through government subsidies. He said renewable energy will be unable to replace fossil fuels for the foreseeable future.
"One area where experts agree is that oil and natural gas will continue to be the leading energy sources for decades to come, and it's important that we take action to reduce emissions while providing that energy," Mr. Sommers said.
The wide-ranging framework for social-spending legislation detailed by Mr. Biden includes expanded tax credits for electric vehicles, but a methane tax was dropped after opposition from some lawmakers. The executives said they didn't always agree with every policy position taken by the industry's trade groups.
At the end of the roughly six-hour hearing, Rep. Carolyn B. Maloney (D., N.Y.), the committee's chairwoman, said she would subpoena the companies to compel documents requested by Democrats that she said the companies hadn't provided.
Republican committee members, at times, came to the companies' defense and used the hearing as an opportunity to criticize Biden administration policies they said are causing soaring energy prices. Rep. Jim Jordan (R., Ohio) said the companies should increase their production to alleviate energy shortages.
Credit: By Katy Stech Ferek and Christopher M. Matthews

U.S. News: Proposal Includes About $555 Billion In Climate Measures

Author: Restuccia, Andrew; Hughes, Siobhan

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/u-s-news-proposal-includes-about-555-billion/docview/2587564890/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Proposal+Includes+About+%24555+Billion+In+Climate+Measures&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;au=Restuccia%2C+Andrew%3BHughes%2C+Siobhan&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Proposal+Includes+About+%24555+Billion+In+Climate+Measures&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;au=Restuccia%2C+Andrew%3BHughes%2C+Siobhan&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: WASHINGTON -- President Biden's wide-ranging framework for social-spending legislation includes about $555 billion for climate-related provisions, a proposal that the White House said will help the U.S. meet its pledge to halve domestic greenhouse-gas emissions by the end of the decade.
Democrats haven't formally signed off on the framework, and lawmakers expect that it could change as they hammer out the details of the measure. It nonetheless gave Mr. Biden something to tout at the international climate summit in Glasgow that begins on Sunday.
The president and his senior aides have been working behind the scenes for weeks to nail down a package of climate measures ahead of the summit, eager to show skeptical world leaders that the U.S. is serious about meeting its commitments to slash emissions. Mr. Biden has pledged to cut U.S. emissions 50% to 52% below 2005 levels by 2030.
"This framework makes the most significant investment to deal with the climate crisis that has ever, ever happened -- beyond any other advanced nation in the world," Mr. Biden said in a speech at the White House on Thursday.
The climate provisions in the legislation alone likely wouldn't be enough to meet the target, according to outside analysts. White House officials are planning a series of climate regulations to help achieve the remaining reductions, including methane rules for oil and gas production and more stringent emissions limits on vehicles.
During a closed-door meeting with House Democrats on Thursday, Mr. Biden said the legislation was a test of the U.S. political system.
"The rest of the world wonders whether we can function," he said, according to a person familiar with his remarks.
Later in the meeting, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) said, "When the president gets off that plane we want him to have a vote of confidence from this Congress," according to the person.
The White House said the $555 billion for climate-related provisions is the largest such investment in history.
The climate measures include:
-- $320 billion in 10-year expanded tax credits for utility- and residential-scale renewable energy development, improved electric transmission and storage, electric vehicles and clean energy manufacturing;
-- $105 billion to boost resilience to the effects of climate change, such as wildfires and droughts;
-- $110 billion to grow U.S. supply chains for renewable energy technology;
-- $20 billion to motivate the government to purchase cutting-edge energy technologies.
The package also sets aside an unspecified amount of money for a Civilian Climate Corps, with the aim of hiring 300,000 workers for projects such as planting trees and cleaning streams.
The agreement doesn't include a $150 billion program opposed by Sen. Joe Manchin (D., W.Va.) aimed at pushing utilities to generate more electricity from clean sources. Lawmakers said at least some of the money from that program -- which one outside analysis said would have helped Mr. Biden meet up to one-third of his emissions-reduction goal -- had been redeployed to achieve greenhouse-gas reductions through alternative means.
The White House didn't detail all of the climate provisions and Democrats were waiting to hear whether the framework also includes fossil fuel-related measures meant to appease Mr. Manchin.
Credit: By Andrew Restuccia and Siobhan Hughes

U.S. News: Progressives Seize the Moment In Blocking Infrastructure Bill

Author: Andrews, Natalie

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/u-s-news-progressives-seize-moment-blocking/docview/2587564886/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Progressives+Seize+the+Moment+In+Blocking+Infrastructure+Bill&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;au=Andrews%2C+Natalie&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=U.S.+News%3A+Progressives+Seize+the+Moment+In+Blocking+Infrastructure+Bill&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.6&amp;au=Andrews%2C+Natalie&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: WASHINGTON -- Progressive lawmakers again flexed their muscles on Democrats' agenda, blocking party leaders' planned vote on infrastructure even as they endorsed President Biden's new framework for a sprawling social-spending and climate plan.
Liberal lawmakers have held up the roughly $1 trillion infrastructure package for months as leverage to ensure a separate, now-$1.85 trillion social-spending and climate package also advanced. On Thursday, neither a new White House framework laying out details of the spending plan nor a pitch from Mr. Biden himself could persuade them to back a quick vote on the stalled public-works bill.
"We intend to vote for both bills when the Build Back Better Act is ready," said Rep. Pramila Jayapal, chair of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, using the Democrats' preferred name for their social-spending and climate package.
The caucus formally endorsed the framework, which includes funding for child-care subsidies, universal prekindergarten, tax breaks for families, in-home care for elderly and disabled Americans, as well as tax credits aimed at combating climate change. But members worried the bill wasn't set in stone and expressed unease over where Democratic senators stood, leading them to reject calls from House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) for a quick vote.
Roughly 30 members of the caucus are committed to opposing the infrastructure bill until there is a clear agreement on the social and climate bill, according to aides. Those lawmakers want a commitment that all 50 Democratic senators in the evenly split chamber support the framework, and they want the House to vote on the two bills together.
Rep. Juan Vargas (D., Calif.) left a meeting of the progressive caucus saying he's a "no" until he has more guarantees on the social-spending package. "I don't trust what the senators are going to do," he said.
Passing the infrastructure package, which includes about $550 billion in new spending, would show momentum for Mr. Biden's agenda.
Progressives said they were concerned that Mr. Biden's framework failed to gain a robust endorsement from Sens. Joe Manchin of West Virginia and Kyrsten Sinema of Arizona, two centrists who have fought to trim the overall cost of the bill as well as cut many programs sought by progressives.
Both Mr. Manchin and Ms. Sinema praised the progress in the talks, but neither offered an explicit endorsement of the framework. Democrats are advancing the social-spending and climate plan through the Senate using a process called reconciliation, which enables the party to pass the bill with just a simple majority in the face of united GOP opposition.
"I think everyone is very clear that the biggest problem we have here is Manchin and Sinema," said Rep. Ruben Gallego (D., Ariz.). "They don't trust them, we need to hear from them that they're actually in agreement with the president's framework."
Thursday's tensions marked the latest turn in the tug of war between the party's centrist and progressive wings to advance the two packages. While the infrastructure bill waits for a vote, Democrats have struggled to put together an outline on the parallel bill, with complex negotiations on the price tag and tax plans making for slow progress.
Centrist Democrats and others who had pushed to pass the infrastructure bill worried that by blocking the vote, the progressives had put the bill at risk of never passing, and may have put the fragile House majority at risk by denying Congress a bipartisan victory.
"I am hopeful that, ultimately, common sense will prevail and a small faction of the party will join the broader effort to help pass President Biden's Bipartisan Infrastructure Bill, get shovels in the ground, and people to work," said Rep. Josh Gottheimer (D., N.J.).
Democrats can afford to lose only three votes in the closely divided House, meaning progressives can easily sink a bill if they remain opposed. While some House Republicans have indicated they could support the bill, which drew the support of 19 GOP senators, they likely would withhold their votes until Democrats had enough votes to pass it on their own.
Mrs. Pelosi, who previously called off a promised vote on infrastructure in the face of progressive opposition, tried to rally House Democrats in their morning meeting with Mr. Biden, telling lawmakers that "in order for us to have success, we must succeed today." She also tried to respond to demands from members for legislative text, posting a version of the bill and encouraging members to read its more than 2,400 pages.
"For those who said 'I want to see text,' the text is there," she said, "for you to review, for you to complain about."
But as progressives remained unmoved, the party on Thursday again put off a vote, instead opting for a short-term extension of highway funding.
Progressives say they have already had to sacrifice some priorities they originally sought, such as free community college and 12 weeks of paid family leave, as the social-spending plan's price tag was winnowed from $3.5 trillion. They also wanted to give Medicare broad powers to negotiate on drug prices and expand the program to cover vision, dental and hearing coverage.
Asked about progressives' concerns on Wednesday, White House press secretary Jen Psaki said Mr. Biden was working to get both packages passed, but would leave the sequence or timing to Congress. She also questioned whether any Democrats would vote against the infrastructure bill.
Credit: By Natalie Andrews

World News: Biden Aims to Ease Tensions at Summits

Author: Lucey, Catherine; Dalton, Matthew

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-biden-aims-ease-tensions-at-summits/docview/2587564846/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Biden+Aims+to+Ease+Tensions+at+Summits&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;au=Lucey%2C+Catherine%3BDalton%2C+Matthew&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+Biden+Aims+to+Ease+Tensions+at+Summits&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.8&amp;au=Lucey%2C+Catherine%3BDalton%2C+Matthew&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: President Biden will push allies to do more to confront climate change and seek progress on a global minimum tax during a foreign trip that follows a bumpy stretch on the world stage and a late sprint to advance his agenda at home.
Following a celebratory trip overseas in June aimed at strengthening U.S. alliances, Mr. Biden's five-day tour to Italy and Scotland will include efforts to ease recent tensions. His administration is coping with frustration over the U.S. exit from Afghanistan and a diplomatic dust-up with France after it was cut out of a deal to supply nuclear submarines to Australia.
In the weeks leading up to the Group of 20 nations meeting in Rome and the Glasgow climate summit, Mr. Biden has worked to win agreement with congressional Democrats on a social-policy and climate bill and a separate infrastructure package. The administration also hopes to show it can still meet goals to cut emissions, despite setbacks in Congress.
Mr. Biden's priorities for the trip include working with allies on climate change, energy prices, supply-chain issues and a new global minimum tax.
White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan played down any tensions, saying the U.S. and Europe are "aligned and united on the major elements of the global agenda." Mr. Sullivan said the president would make gains abroad even if the fate of much of his domestic agenda remained unresolved, saying the other leaders understand the process takes time.
The leaders of China and Russia aren't expected at either gathering. Mr. Biden's foreign policy has focused on countering the economic rise of China.
Mr. Biden first heads to Italy, where the second Roman Catholic president is set to go to Vatican City for an audience Friday with Pope Francis. They are expected to discuss issues including climate, Covid-19 and poverty. The visit comes amid controversy among U.S. bishops over Mr. Biden's support for abortion rights.
Also on Friday, Mr. Biden will meet with French President Emmanuel Macron. France was furious at being cut out of the Australia deal.
Unknown are what steps France now seeks from the Biden administration. At a minimum, Mr. Macron wants backing from the U.S. for his vision of strategic autonomy, in which the European Union would build out its own defense capability and rely less on support from the U.S. Mr. Macron's idea is controversial in Europe, and the U.S. historically has been skeptical of Europe developing a defense capability independent of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Mr. Biden will meet with other leaders during both summits. Mr. Sullivan said he expects a meeting between Mr. Biden and Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who this week backed off a threat to expel the U.S. ambassador and the top envoys of nine other Western countries who called for the release of a jailed philanthropist. In recent years, American-Turkish relations have cratered over clashing interests over the war in Syria, human-rights issues within Turkey and Ankara's purchases of Russian arms systems.
Mr. Sullivan said Mr. Biden also would attend a meeting of allies on how to bring Iran back into compliance with the nuclear accord.
At the G-20, an important issue for the U.S. is an agreement among nearly 140 countries to overhaul global tax rules, which is expected to receive backing from leaders.
The reform sets out a global minimum corporate tax of 15%, targeted at preventing companies from exploiting low-tax jurisdictions. The Biden administration has pushed for the move, arguing that the floor set by the global minimum tax was a victory for the U.S. and its ability to raise money from companies.
Mr. Biden is to attend the climate summit in Glasgow on Monday and Tuesday, and is expected to give an address while there.
The president is hoping to stress that the U.S. is serious about climate-change efforts, even if he is struggling to pass his agenda in Congress.
Credit: By Catherine Lucey and Matthew Dalton

President Pitches Revamped $1.85 Trillion Spending Plan

Author: Duehren, Andrew; Thomas, Ken; Andrews, Natalie

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/president-pitches-revamped-1-85-trillion-spending/docview/2587560067/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=President+Pitches+Revamped+%241.85+Trillion+Spending+Plan&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Duehren%2C+Andrew%3BThomas%2C+Ken%3BAndrews%2C+Natalie&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=President+Pitches+Revamped+%241.85+Trillion+Spending+Plan&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-29&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Duehren%2C+Andrew%3BThomas%2C+Ken%3BAndrews%2C+Natalie&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: WASHINGTON -- Pushing to reach a deal after months of talks, the White House released a $1.85 trillion social-spending and climate framework for a still-developing proposal, but it fell short of convincing progressives to quickly approve a parallel infrastructure bill.
President Biden met with House Democrats in the morning to pitch them on the new framework, a far slimmer piece of legislation than the $3.5 trillion the party had originally outlined. Democrats have been rushing to complete negotiations on the bill so that they can also move forward with the public works legislation, which passed the Senate over the summer but has languished in the House.
Party leaders initially signaled they wanted to hold a vote on the infrastructure bill later Thursday, but abandoned that plan in the evening in the face of progressive opposition, instead approving a short-term patch for transportation programs that were expiring at the end of the month. Progressives endorsed Mr. Biden's framework but said they still needed to see more detail of the social-policy and climate bill before they could support the infrastructure legislation.
The developments frustrated Democrats' hopes for a high-profile policy win as Mr. Biden headed to Europe. The White House released the framework just hours before the president boarded Air Force One for Rome, where he is set to meet with Group of 20 leaders before he attends the Glasgow, Scotland, climate summit. The White House is eager to notch wins on two central pillars of the president's agenda to firm up his sagging poll numbers and bolster Democrats' case with voters, with a test coming next week in gubernatorial elections in Virginia and New Jersey.
In a televised midday speech, Mr. Biden said: "No one got everything they wanted, including me, but that's what compromise is."
The White House framework released Thursday called for major funding for child-care subsidies, universal prekindergarten, tax breaks for families, in-home care for elderly and disabled people, as well as tax credits aimed at combating climate change. Several party priorities were absent, including a national paid leave program, while the fate of others, including a push to allow the government to negotiate drug prices, remained uncertain.
House Speaker Nancy Pelosi (D., Calif.) had pressed for an immediate vote on the infrastructure bill following the release of the framework, even as many progressive lawmakers indicated they weren't ready to support it. A person familiar with the vote counting said there were about 30 progressives who still wanted Democrats to provide more clarity on the social-policy and climate bill before moving forward with a vote on the infrastructure bill. Vice President Kamala Harris was calling some lawmakers to try to persuade them to back the measure.
Wrangling all factions of the party behind a particular set of ideas has proven challenging, especially as congressional leaders and the administration have jettisoned some of progressives' favored proposals in the face of objections from moderates.
Mr. Biden headed to Italy on Thursday to begin a series of international meetings, and Mrs. Pelosi told Democrats during the morning meeting that they should pass the infrastructure slice of Mr. Biden's agenda by the time he lands.
"The president has asked for our vote today," Mrs. Pelosi told Democrats, according to the person familiar with the meeting.
But progressives, who for months have blocked the infrastructure bill as leverage to keep the social-spending bill on track, made clear they weren't yet ready to drop their opposition. Their demand forced Democrats to delay a vote on the public works bill for the second time in two months, though progressives said they hoped to move the bills in the House next week.
"There are too many no votes for the [infrastructure] to pass today," said Rep. Pramila Jayapal (D., Wash.), the chairwoman of the Congressional Progressive Caucus.
Progressives said they needed more certainty about the social-spending bill's contents and its fate in the Senate. But Ms. Jayapal said progressives would back off their insistence that the Senate pass the social bill before the House could move on infrastructure.
"We're going to trust the president on the Senate vote," Ms. Jayapal said. "But we do need the text and we do need the votes on both bills in the House at the same time."
House Democrats released a text of the social-policy and climate legislation, beginning the process for formally considering it, though Mrs. Pelosi acknowledged she would likely amend it. "There's some clarifications that will come forth because it's always moving a bit," she said.
Many of the changes Democrats have made to the bill have been the product of negotiations with two key holdouts in the Senate: Sens. Kyrsten Sinema (D., Ariz.) and Joe Manchin (D., W.Va.).
Neither Mr. Manchin nor Ms. Sinema explicitly endorsed the new framework.
"This is all in the hands of the House right now, this is. I have worked in good faith and I look forward to continuing working in good faith," Mr. Manchin said. Ms. Sinema said in a statement that Democrats had "made significant progress on the proposed budget reconciliation package."
Those statements did little to ease the concerns of House Democrats who worry about the pair further paring back the framework or ultimately opposing it entirely. "It's about the substance, and basically it's trust of Manchin and Sinema, that's the problem," said Rep. Steve Cohen (D., Tenn.).
The infrastructure bill, which showers funding on highways, rail and water systems, would reauthorize a series of transportation programs that are set to expire Sunday. The reauthorization legislation, which the Senate quickly adopted, will extend the programs through Dec. 3, when Congress will face several other major deadlines on government funding and the debt limit.
Democrats have been honing their mammoth spending legislation for weeks, seeking to both slim the package as well as find revenue to pay for new programs.
The plan includes a one-year extension of the expanded child tax credit through 2022, plus a provision making that break permanently available to low-income families that don't pay income taxes. It funds six years of universal prekindergarten, six years of child-care subsidies, and $150 billion to support long-term care for elderly and disabled Americans.
The framework also sets aside $555 billion for climate-related provisions, including $320 billion in 10-year expanded tax credits for renewable energy, transmission, electric vehicles and clean energy manufacturing.
A central challenge in the talks has been crafting ways to raise revenue for the package after Ms. Sinema objected to many of the tax increases.
A new surtax in the White House framework will be 5% on adjusted gross income above $10 million and a further 3% on adjusted gross income over $25 million, senior administration officials said. Those levies would hit high-income people but wouldn't address billionaires who are seeing their wealth increase without reporting much taxable income.
The plan will also include a 15% minimum tax on profitable corporations, higher taxes on U.S. companies' foreign income and money to increase the Internal Revenue Service enforcement staff. A 1% excise tax on corporate stock buybacks is part of the plan.
The tax plans do focus on high-income households and corporations, but other revenue-raising ideas proposed by the administration appear to lack enough support for now. Those include a tax on billionaires' unrealized capital gains, a rule requiring banks to report account flows to the IRS and higher corporate tax rates. Democrats said they would continue to seek changes.
The framework didn't include a popular provision to allow Medicare to negotiate with drugmakers to lower the cost of prescription drugs, which a senior White House official said reflected Mr. Biden's assessment of what could pass Congress. But lawmakers said the proposal could still make it into the final bill.
---
Kristina Peterson, Alex Leary, Richard Rubin and Lindsay Wise contributed to this article.

Activist Investor Presses Shell To Split --- Third Point wants the oil giant to create a separate business for renewable energy

Author: Lombardo, Cara; McFarlane, Sarah

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/activist-investor-presses-shell-split-third-point/docview/2586769611/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Activist+Investor+Presses+Shell+To+Split+---+Third+Point+wants+the+oil+giant+to+create+a+separate+business+for+renewable+energy&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-28&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Lombardo%2C+Cara%3BMcFarlane%2C+Sarah&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=Activist+Investor+Presses+Shell+To+Split+---+Third+Point+wants+the+oil+giant+to+create+a+separate+business+for+renewable+energy&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-28&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.1&amp;au=Lombardo%2C+Cara%3BMcFarlane%2C+Sarah&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: Daniel Loeb's Third Point LLC has taken a large stake in Royal Dutch Shell PLC and is urging the oil giant to separate into two companies to retain and attract investors as many flee stocks seen as environmentally unfriendly.
The activist is the latest to pressure a major oil company to change its strategic direction, as the firms face calls to reduce fossil-fuel investments and pivot to renewable energy amid concerns about climate change. Upstart hedge fund Engine No. 1 waged a successful campaign to win seats on the board of Exxon Mobil Corp. in May.
Third Point's stake is worth well over $500 million, making the hedge fund one of Shell's largest investors, people familiar with the matter said.
In a letter to its investors Wednesday that was viewed by The Wall Street Journal, the activist said Shell should consider creating two stand-alone companies: one with legacy businesses such as refining that would provide steady cash flow and another that houses renewables and other units requiring substantial investment. It reasons that doing so would clarify the company's strategy and appeal to different sets of investors who have been making competing demands of the Anglo-Dutch company.
Among the major oil companies, Shell has been faster-moving than peers such as Exxon when it comes to remaking its business and reducing emissions. It isn't clear whether Shell will be receptive to the idea of separating into two companies. Third Point said in the letter the two sides have been in early discussions.
Shell has a market value of nearly $200 billion, according to S&P Capital IQ. Third Point, which says in the letter that Shell is trading at a discount to its peers despite having a better collection of businesses, estimates that a new company including Shell's liquefied natural gas, renewables and marketing businesses could have the same enterprise value as the company in its current form.
Shell said Wednesday that it "regularly reviews and evaluates the company's strategy" and that it welcomes open dialogue with all shareholders, including Third Point. Shell also said its strategy had been endorsed by the majority of its shareholders in a vote earlier this year. Shell is set to report its third-quarter earnings Thursday.
The role of climate change in investment decisions has taken center stage this year, as many institutional investors pare holdings in pollution-heavy industries and activists urge companies to remake themselves faster.
In May, a Dutch court ruled that Shell must cut its emissions by 45% by 2030. Shell has said it plans to appeal the decision.
Earlier this year, the company laid out plans to accelerate its shift to low-carbon energy by reducing its oil production and investing more in areas including biofuels and electric-vehicle-charging infrastructure. Shell agreed to sell its assets in the Permian Basin to ConocoPhillips in September for $9.5 billion.
The pivot to low-carbon energy is seen as challenging because it requires investment in areas in which oil companies don't necessarily have competitive advantages and with potentially lower returns.
Shell's new strategy has failed to excite investors who have said the uncertainties around the energy transition make it difficult to predict future profits. Though Shell stock has risen more than 30% this year, it is little changed over the past two decades. The shares rose nearly 2% after the Journal reported on Third Point's stake.
Analysts said shareholders could be receptive to splitting the company.
"Investors have generally pushed back against the hybrid model and are looking for ways to see these companies crystallize value" by carving out lower-carbon businesses, said Christyan Malek, an analyst at JP Morgan.
Some European oil companies are already considering splitting out their lower-carbon operations to offer investors more focus, including Italy's Eni SpA and Spain's Repsol SA.
Others in the industry, including Shell, have argued that their legacy fossil-fuel businesses are key to funding shareholder payouts and investments in lower-carbon energy.
"At first sight I don't think splitting Shell will help in the fight against the climate crisis because we think it's better to generate as much cash as possible from existing businesses and invest this in renewable energy," said Mark van Baal of Follow This, a group of more than 7,000 shareholders in oil companies including Shell. The group has pushed Shell to accelerate its shift to lower-carbon energy.
Political pressure on oil companies is also increasing. Executives from top oil companies including Shell and Exxon are set to be questioned by a congressional committee in Washington on Thursday about whether they knew about the role of fossil fuels in global warming.
The oil industry was hard hit during the pandemic by the fall in demand for gasoline for cars and jet fuel for planes, with some companies resorting to dividend cuts. Shell reduced its dividend by two-thirds in April 2020, the first cut since World War II. This year, oil prices have rallied as demand has recovered amid a pickup in economic activity. That has buoyed profits at Shell in recent quarters.
New York-based Third Point has more than $19 billion under management. While it is well-known for activism campaigns, including one at Intel Corp., the firm also makes typical hedge-fund and friendly investments. Intel tapped VMware Inc.'s Pat Gelsinger as its new chief executive earlier this year a few weeks after Third Point urged the chip-making giant to make changes, a move the hedge fund applauded.
Third Point's flagship fund is up about 30% so far this year, according to the letter.
Credit: By Cara Lombardo and Sarah McFarlane

World News: South America Drought Cripples River-Dependent Paraguay

Author: Forero, Juan

http://abc.cardiff.ac.uk/login?url=https://www.proquest.com/newspapers/world-news-south-america-drought-cripples-river/docview/2586283644/se-2?accountid=9883

Abstract: None available.

Links: https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+South+America+Drought+Cripples+River-Dependent+Paraguay&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-27&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Forero%2C+Juan&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

https://librarysearch.cardiff.ac.uk/openurl/44WHELF_CAR/CAR_VU1??url_ver=Z39.88-2004&amp;rft_val_fmt=info:ofi/fmt:kev:mtx:journal&amp;genre=article&amp;sid=ProQ:ProQ%3Aabiglobal&amp;atitle=World+News%3A+South+America+Drought+Cripples+River-Dependent+Paraguay&amp;title=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;issn=00999660&amp;date=2021-10-27&amp;volume=&amp;issue=&amp;spage=A.10&amp;au=Forero%2C+Juan&amp;isbn=&amp;jtitle=Wall+Street+Journal&amp;btitle=&amp;rft_id=info:eric/&amp;rft_id=info:doi/

Full text: HERNANDARIAS, Paraguay -- Most years, when rains are normal, four Olympic swimming pools worth of water passes each second through the mammoth Itaipu Dam, churning out electricity for both Paraguay and Brazil and allowing ships and barges to export grains as far away as China.
Since 2019, however, rainfall levels have dropped sharply -- not just here, but in much of the heart of South America -- and left a vast swath baking in drought. Dozens of hydroelectric dams in Brazil have sputtered, driving up energy prices there. And the river transport of soybeans, the regional cash cow, has been severely hampered in the grain hub of Rosario, Argentina.
But it is Paraguay, a landlocked country of seven million encircled by giant neighbors and dependent on two large rivers, that has been hardest hit, say government officials, climate scientists and the business people who depend on the waterways. The dry season occurs annually, but this region hasn't suffered through a drought this extreme since the 1940s, they say.
With world leaders preparing for the global climate conference that begins on Sunday in Glasgow, Scotland, Paraguay offers one look at what changing weather patterns may mean, long term, to those countries most vulnerable to the effects of climate change.
This California-size country of grain fields, cattle pastures and groves of fruit is powered by its two rivers, the Parana and the Paraguay, together measuring 4,657 miles. The rivers provide drinking water for cities and serve as arteries connecting Paraguay to the outside world -- the highways by which agricultural exports help feed 80 million people abroad while permitting imports of fuel, machinery, chemicals and fertilizers.
"It's been 25 years since we produced such little energy," said Hugo Zarate, the superintendent of operations at Itaipu, the world's second-biggest dam in electricity production after China's Three Gorges Dam. "This drought prolonged itself all of 2020, and we thought in 2021 we'd do better. But the drought got worse, and the water flow decreased even more."
The consequences for Paraguay, which uses its rivers for 96% of its commerce, is seen at the private grain silos and loading port on the Parana River run by the agro-industry giant, Trociuk Industries.
Earlier this month, the water level was so low the giant barge convoys in a country with the third-largest barge fleet couldn't haul grain for export. Instead, the grain was loaded on trucks that had to take two-lane roads to the deeper Paraguay River, where barges were loading at 50% capacity.
The cost is huge -- and unsustainable. While a truck can carry 30 tons of grain, a barge can carry up to 2,000 tons. And the convoy of barges that normally ply the rivers here can haul 30,000 tons, a job that would take 350 trucks.
At the Itaipu dam on the Parana, water flow has been down since 2019 by more than 30%. And revenue for Paraguay from the dam is projected to tumble 40% this year to $365 million, 2.8% of the government's budget, about half of what it was in 2016. This year, the dam -- run jointly by Brazil and Paraguay -- is expected to generate 65,000 gigawatt-hours, down from the record of 103,000 GW hours in 2016.
The drop has strained Brazil's energy grid, which depends on Itaipu for 11% of its power. Brazil's president, Jair Bolsonaro, asked Brazilians to avoid using elevators and otherwise cut back on power use. "Help us," he said last month on his Facebook page.
While droughts can happen regularly and be caused by complex circumstances, one factor in the long dry spells might be found hundreds of miles away in the Amazon. Some climate scientists say evidence appears to show that deforestation in the world's largest rainforest is altering weather patterns, with the dry season growing hotter and drier as rain levels fall below normal in the rainy season.
An area about the size of Missouri has been deforested in the Brazilian Amazon since 2004. Farmland has replaced the trees that Lonnie Thompson, a climatologist who studies hydrology in Latin America, says produce much of the rainwater through evaporation.
Dr. Norman Breuer, a Paraguayan scientist who studies the impact of climate on agriculture, said that while it is probable that climate change may be leading to longer, drier droughts, he said it can't be determined with certainty until there is a long trend line of intense dry seasons to examine. But he said it is clear, for now, that the La Nina weather phenomenon signals more drought for this coming year.
Credit: By Juan Forero
